item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: May 30
item.description: A sand sculpture to spread awareness about the adverse effects of tobacco consumption on the eve of World No Tobacco Day.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A sand sculpture created by artist Sudarshan Pattnaik in Puri, Orissa, as part of an awareness campaign on the eve of World No Tobacco Day. The World Health Organization first designated May 31 as a day to spread awareness about the adverse effects of tobacco consumption in 1987.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Homage Paid to ‘Rite of Spring,’ With Stravinsky and Without
item.description: Theaters in London and Paris marked the centennial of a revolutionary, game-changing moment in modern music and dance.
item.dc:creator: By ROSLYN SULCAS
item.media:description: A scene from the Akram Khan Company's "iTMOi" (In the Mind of Igor), inspired by "The Rite of Spring."

item.title: At War Blog: Globalization Creates a New Worry: Enemy Convergence
item.description: Adm. James G. Stavridis, who stepped down this month as NATO’s supreme commander, is concerned about previously unrelated adversaries, who not only might combine in operations, but also share resources, know-how, weapons and technology and personnel.
item.category: Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER
item.media:description: In a speech in London in 2009, Adm. James G. Stavridis said that NATO should seek out new ways to convince people of its role in global security.

item.title: DealBook: Shuanghui Agrees to Buy Smithfield for $4.7 Billion
item.description: The $4.7 billion offer by Shuanghui International for Smithfield Foods is one of the biggest moves yet by a Chinese company into the United States.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED and DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: India Ink: For Kolkata Rape Victim, a Lonely Wait for Justice
item.description: A mother of two teenage daughters, who was victimized more than a year ago, found little support from the government or the legal system.
item.dc:creator: By SWATI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: A demonstration in Kolkata, West Bengal, on Feb. 14, which was part of the 'One Billion Rising' campaign, a global initiative to oppose violence against women.

item.title: U.N. Expert Calls for Halt on Military Robots
item.description: Although no countries currently use such weapons, the technology is available and human rights groups are campaigning to pre-empt deployment.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Way of the World: Sexist Mores of Super-Rich Hurt Us All
item.description: It is the striking fact that at the summits of high finance there are no women, and it is commonplace to believe that there never will be any.
item.dc:creator: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND | REUTERS

item.title: Assad Says Syria Has Received Advanced Missiles From Russia
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad said in an interview to be broadcast Thursday that Russia had delivered the air defense missiles, which Israel has said present a threat to its security.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: The Swiss Offer Some Economic Advice to Europe
item.description: Switzerland, outside the European Union and the euro zone, has fared better than most during the Continent’s economic downturn. That has given it an opportunity to offer advice to its neighbors on the balance between austerity and growth.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Swiss women in traditional dress celebrated the Feast of Corpus Christi in Appenzell on Thursday.

item.title: Bulgarian Parliament Names Plamen Oresharski Prime Minister
item.description: The Parliament narrowly voted in a new technocratic government to be led by Plamen Oresharski, a former finance minister who is regarded as competent and nonpartisan.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW BRUNWASSER

item.title: Suspect in Soldier’s Killing Is Charged in London
item.description: Michael Adebowale, who is accused of killing the soldier, Lee Rigby, on May 22, was charged with murder and with possessing an illegal firearm.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Pakistani Taliban Pick New Number Two After Drone Strike: Sources
item.description: Pakistani Taliban militants have chosen a new deputy commander to replace their previous second-in-command who was killed in a U.S. drone strike in the North Waziristan region, sources in the militant group said on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In China, Second Thoughts About ‘Dishonest Americans’ Column
item.description: A newspaper column in People’s Daily, the Communist Party mouthpiece, about “Dishonest Americans,” draws criticism from many Chinese who accuse it of hypocrisy.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A store clerk adjusting the neon lights on a "Friendship" store sign in central Beijing.

item.title: Israeli Plan to Conscript Ultra-Orthodox Advances
item.description: A government panel approved a plan to phase out exemptions from military service for ultra-Orthodox Jewish men, a big step toward regulating a controversial issue.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 30
item.description: Attack on a Red Cross compound in Afghanistan; Buddhist mobs in Myanmar; a Chinese company buys a major U.S. pork producer; Titian in Rome; and a dazzling match at the French Open.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: An Afghan police officer ran on the roof of a house near the International Red Cross building Wednesday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Does Spain’s History Provide a Lesson in Syria’s Civil War?
item.description: Some of those arguing for greater Western involvement in Syria have pointed to parallels with the Spanish Civil War, in which the democratic powers stood aside. Are they right? How much can history provide a model for present-day policy?
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: A boy walked in the rubble of Syria's Salqin city on Tuesday after a missile attack.

item.title: India Ink: For Farmers Fearing Drought, Auroville Offers Some Lessons
item.description: Farmers in the small township north of Pondicherry are adopting dynamic farming techniques to fight the uncertain monsoon.
item.dc:creator: By ANUPAMA CHANDRASEKARAN
item.media:description: Bottle gourds growing in the Pebble Garden in Auroville, Tamil Nadu.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Venezuela: Anger Over Colombian President’s Meeting With Opposition Leader
item.description: The Venezuelan government reacted angrily to a meeting Wednesday between President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia and Henrique Capriles Radonski, who lost a presidential election to Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Bombing Kills Members of Wedding Party
item.description: A car bomb killed about 20 people in a wedding party in a Baghdad neighborhood on Wednesday and wounded more than 50 others, according to officials.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Oldest Known Torah Scroll Found, Scholar Says
item.description: An Italian scholar said Wednesday that he had discovered the oldest known complete Torah scroll, dating from the 12th to the 13th century.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Salvadoran Court Denies Abortion to Ailing Woman
item.description: In a 4-to-1 ruling, El Salvador’s highest court said that “the rights of the mother cannot be privileged over those” of the fetus. But the woman’s lawyer described the decision as “misogynistic.”
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY and GENE PALUMBO

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Venezuela: New Details in Strip Club Shooting
item.description: The State Department said that one of the men wounded was a member of the United States armed services and the other was a civilian.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Bulgaria: Naming of Prime Minister Ends Stalemate
item.description: The Parliament elected Plamen Oresharski on Wednesday as prime minister, ending a three-month stalemate after the previous government resigned in February amid protests.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Wariness Over a Deal Intended to Deliver More Pork to China
item.description: A Chinese takeover of a large American pork producer has prompted concern about China’s expanding role in the American food supply and the implications that might have for food safety.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHANIE STROM
item.media:credit: Top from Left: J.Scott Applewhite/AP; Skip Nall/Digital Vision via Getty Images; Gerry Broome/AP; Mid from Left; J.Scott Applewhite/AP; Andrew Scrivani for the NYT: Genaro C. Armas/AP; Bot from Left: Fred R. Conrad/The NYT; Evan Sung for The NYT; Karsten Moran for The NYT

item.title: Chances of U.N. Peace Talks on Syria Appear Dim as Both Sides Dig In
item.description: As Syria’s foreign minister said President Bashar al-Assad would remain in office until elections next year and might even seek another term, the main opposition coalition said Mr. Assad must “step down.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HALA DROUBI
